questions.text: Patient was started on HAART. What is used to monitor the efficacy of treatment.
questions.solution:
HAART stands for highly active anti retroviral therapy. Treatment that uses a combination of three or more drugs to treat HIV infection.

HAART should be started as early as possible once the patient is diagnosed with HIV.
Even If there is needle stick injury, It should be started as soon as possible.

Viral load is one parameter which is helpful to monitor effect of HAART.

P24 antigen has no role in monitoring of HAART

HIV 1 antibody has no role in monitoring of HAART

Viral serotype has no role in monitoring of HAART

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice B: P24 antigen - The p24 antigen is an early marker of HIV infection and is primarily used in diagnosis (e.g., in acute HIV infection). However, it is not useful for monitoring treatment response, as its levels decline once antibodies develop and viral replication is suppressed.
  • Choice C: HIV-1 antibody - HIV-1 antibodies remain detectable for life, even with effective HAART. Since antibody presence does not correlate with viral suppression, it is not a reliable indicator of treatment efficacy.
  • Choice D: Viral serotype - HIV viral serotyping is used for epidemiological studies (e.g., identifying different HIV subtypes in populations) but has no role in treatment monitoring.

Key Takeaways:

  • HIV viral load is the best parameter to monitor HAART efficacy.
  • A declining or undetectable viral load indicates successful treatment.
  • P24 antigen, HIV-1 antibody, and viral serotype are not useful for monitoring HAART response.

questions.text: A patient visited Africa and died of a disease. Autopsy showed intra nuclear Torres bodies. Which vaccine strain could have prevented this disease?
questions.solution:
Torres bodies are seen in yellow fever.

Torres bodies are amorphous eosinophilic nuclear inclusions associated with yellow fever.

Yellow fever is caused by arbovirus. It is caused by virus of flavivirus genus of flaviviridae family. Disease spread by mosquito or infected monkey from where the infection may be epidemic. Torres bodies may be seen in the liver with councilman and villela bodies.

Yellow fever is spread by species of mosquito common to areas of Africa and south America. In india it is not seen because vector which transmits is not seen.

Clinical feature include fever, headache, nausea and vomiting. Serious case may show fatal heart liver or kidney condition.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: SA 14-14-2 - This is the live-attenuated Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccine, used primarily in Asia. It does not provide protection against yellow fever.
  • Choice C: Nakayama - This is another Japanese encephalitis vaccine strain, but it is an inactivated vaccine. Like SA 14-14-2, it is not protective against yellow fever.
  • Choice D: Jeryl-Lynn - This is the mumps vaccine strain, used in combination vaccines like MMR (measles, mumps, rubella). It has no role in yellow fever prevention.

Key Takeaways:

  • Torres bodies are seen in yellow fever and are intranuclear inclusions in the liver.
  • Yellow fever is caused by a flavivirus and transmitted by mosquitoes in Africa and South America.
  • The 17D vaccine is the standard live-attenuated vaccine for yellow fever prevention.
  • SA 14-14-2, Nakayama, and Jeryl-Lynn vaccines are for other diseases and do not protect against yellow fever.

questions.text: A truck driver admitted with cough and breathlessness. HPE revealed septate hyphae with 45 degree angle branching as shown in the image. Identify the correct pathogen.
questions.solution:
Septate branched hyphae is a feature of Aspergillosis. Branching at 45 degrees also favours aspergillosis.

Rhizopus , mucor and Absidia give aseptate branched hyphae.

Aspergillus have many species. But Aspergillus flavus, Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus niger are common human pathogens.

It causes Aspergilloma in the lungs, where pt has cough and breathlessness.

Mostly it is caused by Aspergillus flavus and A. fumigates.

A niger mostly causes ear infection ( Otomycosis).

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Rhizopus - This fungus belongs to the Mucorales order and has aseptate (coenocytic) hyphae with broad, right-angle (90-degree) branching. It is a common cause of mucormycosis (zygomycosis), especially in diabetic or immunocompromised patients.
  • Choice B: Mucor - Similar to Rhizopus, Mucor also has aseptate, broad hyphae with 90-degree branching and causes mucormycosis. It typically affects the sinuses, brain, and lungs.
  • Choice D: Absidia - Another Mucorales genus that also has aseptate, broad, ribbon-like hyphae with 90-degree branching, causing zygomycosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Aspergillus species have septate hyphae with acute (45-degree) branching, a key diagnostic feature.
  • Rhizopus, Mucor, and Absidia have aseptate hyphae with broad (90-degree) branching and cause mucormycosis.
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis presents with cough and breathlessness, commonly caused by A. fumigatus and A. flavus.
  • niger is more associated with otomycosis (ear infections).

questions.text: A HIV positive person developed fever, cough, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. The infectious agent was in yeast form at 37c and mold form at 22c. Produces red color pigment in the culture. Microscopy shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Talaromycesmarneffi, formerly called penicillium marneffei, was identified in 1956. The organism is endemic to southeast asia where it is an important cause of opportunistic infection in Hiv pt or AIDS related immunodeficiency.

Clinical features are fever, cough ,lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and hepatomegaly.

It is a dimorphic fungus, he is as yeast for at 37 degree celsius and mould form at 22 degree celsius.

It gives red pigment on culture.

Other three fungi do not have all these features, so they all are wrong answer.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Aspergillus versicolor - A species of Aspergillus that can produce pigments, but not dimorphic. Aspergillus species remain in mold form at all temperatures and do not convert to yeast at 37°C, ruling this out.
  • Choice B: Pneumocystis jirovecii - Causes PCP pneumonia in HIV/AIDS patients, but it is a protozoan-like fungus and does not exhibit dimorphism. It also does not produce red pigment in culture.
  • Choice C: Blastomyces dermatitidis - A dimorphic fungus, but it is not associated with red pigment production. It causes blastomycosis, which primarily affects the lungs and skin, but is more common in North America, not Southeast Asia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Talaromyces marneffei is a dimorphic fungus endemic to Southeast Asia, causing opportunistic infections in HIV/AIDS patients.
  • It exists in mold form at 22°C (with red pigment production) and yeast form at 37°C.
  • Clinical presentation includes fever, cough, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.
  • Other fungi (Aspergillus, Pneumocystis, Blastomyces) lack either dimorphism or red pigment production.

questions.text: A farmer came with a cauliflower-like growth on foot. Biopsy showed copper penny or sclerotic bodies. Choose the correct diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous mycotic infection of the feet and lower leg. Etiological agents are soil inhabiting fungi of family dematiaceae.

Fungi responsible are

Fonsecaea pedrosoi

Fonsecaea compactum

Fonsecaea dermatitidis

Phialophora verrucosa

Cladosporium carrionii

Fungus enters the skin by traumatic implantation

Lesions consist of warty cutaneous nodules which resemble the florets of cauliflower.

Biopsy will show copper penny or sclerotic bodies.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Sporotrichosis - Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, a dimorphic fungus that also enters through trauma but leads to nodular lymphangitis (ascending chain of nodules) rather than cauliflower-like lesions. No sclerotic bodies are seen.
  • Choice C: Mycetoma - Also a subcutaneous fungal infection, but it presents with painless swelling, draining sinuses, and granules (black or white grains in discharge). Histopathology shows hyphae, not sclerotic bodies.
  • Choice D: Cutaneous blastomycosis - Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, but it typically presents with ulcerative or verrucous skin lesions, not cauliflower-like warty nodules. It is not associated with sclerotic bodies.

Key Takeaways:

  • Chromoblastomycosis presents with cauliflower-like warty lesions on the feet or legs.
  • Histopathology shows copper penny (sclerotic) bodies, a key diagnostic feature.
  • Caused by dematiaceous fungi like Fonsecaea and Cladosporium species.
  • Other infections (Sporotrichosis, Mycetoma, Blastomycosis) do not show sclerotic bodies and have different clinical presentations.

questions.text: A patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge. Choose the correct medium used to identify the species of this pathogen?
questions.solution:
Given history suggests the candida infection. In candida infection there is curdy white discharge from vagina.

To identify candida species , gram stain can be done, germ tube test is to be performed to differentiate candida albicans or non albicans.

Other manual methods to be performed for further identification. But CHROM agar is alternate of it. In this different species will grow with different color.

So the answer is CHROM agar.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) - A general-purpose fungal growth medium, but it does not differentiate Candida species based on color.
  • Choice B: Bird seed agar - Used for Cryptococcus neoformans identification, not Candida. Cryptococcus forms brown colonies due to melanin production.
  • Choice D: Cornmeal agar - Used to study Candida morphology, particularly pseudohyphae, chlamydospores, and blastoconidia, but not for species differentiation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Candida infection presents with curdy white vaginal discharge (vaginal candidiasis).
  • CHROMagar differentiates Candida species by colony color.
  • SDA supports fungal growth but does not differentiate species.
  • Bird seed agar is for Cryptococcus, and Cornmeal agar is for Candida morphology studies.

questions.text: A post covid female patient presented with hemifacial pain and loosening of left tooth. What should be done based on high priority?
questions.solution:
Post covid complications are many. Mucor Mucormycosis is one of them but in it patient will complain of black material discharge from nose, pain in nose etc which is not there so Nasal swab for mucor is excluded.

Ferritin has no role . S ferritin has no relation to loosening of left tooth and pain.

HbA1C is useful to diagnose diabetes. But in diabetes pt complains of excessive hunger, excessive urination etc
MRI brain has a role because it has hemifacial pain and loosening of left tooth. These are possible as nerves may get involved post COVID and produce this type of complications.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Nasal swab for mucor - While mucormycosis is a known post-COVID complication, it typically presents with:
    • Black necrotic nasal discharge
    • Nasal pain, swelling, or orbital symptoms
    • Rapid tissue destruction (rhinocerebral mucormycosis)
      Since these signs are not present, a nasal swab is not the first priority.
  • Choice B: Ferritin - Ferritin is an inflammatory marker but has no direct role in diagnosing facial pain or tooth loosening.
  • Choice C: HbA1C - While diabetes is a risk factor for post-COVID mucormycosis, testing HbA1C does not directly address the acute neurological or infectious It is useful but not the immediate priority.

Key Takeaways:

  • Post-COVID complications can involve the brain, cranial nerves, or sinuses, leading to hemifacial pain and tooth loosening.
  • MRI brain is the priority to rule out neurological or invasive fungal involvement.
  • Mucormycosis typically presents with black nasal discharge and rapid tissue necrosis.
  • Ferritin and HbA1C are not immediately relevant in this case.

questions.text: A wrestler presented with itch in axilla. The organism produced velvety colonies with underside red color pigment in culture. Microscopy shown pencil shaped macroconidia and abundant microconidia. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here the findings given in the case suggest dermatophyte. Because in dermatophytes there are macro and micro conidia.

The organism has grown as a velvety colony and its underside is red colour suggesting T rubrum.

Microscopy shows pencil shaped macroconidia and abundant microconidia. This finding also favours T rubrum.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice B: T. mentagrophytes - Produces powdery colonies, not velvety. The underside is tan to yellow-brown, not red. Microscopically, cigar-shaped macroconidia are seen, unlike the pencil-shaped ones described here.
  • Choice C: T. schoenleinii - Causes tinea favosa (favus), mainly affecting the scalp, not the axilla. It does not produce abundant microconidia and lacks macroconidia.
  • Choice D: T. tonsurans - A major cause of tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), it rarely produces macroconidia and mainly shows microconidia with irregular shapes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tinea infections (dermatophytosis) are caused by Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton species.
  • rubrum produces velvety colonies with red pigment on the underside and pencil-shaped macroconidia.
  • Other Trichophyton species (T. mentagrophytes, T. schoenleinii, T. tonsurans) have different colony morphology and conidial features.

questions.text: A 28 year old lady was admitted with fever, nausea and anorexia for 2 months. HbsAg positive, anti HBc IgM positive. Anti HCV negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical feature suggestive of Hepatitis B infection.

Serology finding suggests it is acute infection because Anti HBc IgM antibodies are positive.

IgM positivity suggests acute infection.

If igG antibodies are there then it is chronic infection.

Hepatitis C is excluded because Anti HCV antibodies are negative.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Acute Hepatitis C - Excluded because Anti-HCV is negative, meaning there is no HCV infection.
  • Choice B: Chronic Hepatitis C - Also ruled out due to Anti-HCV negativity. Chronic HCV infection is confirmed when Anti-HCV and HCV RNA are positive for more than 6 months.
  • Choice D: Chronic Hepatitis B - In chronic HBV infection, we would expect:
    • HbsAg positive for more than 6 months
    • Anti-HBc IgG positive (not IgM)
      Since this patient has Anti-HBc IgM positivity, it confirms acute HBV infection, not chronic.

Key Takeaways:

  • HbsAg positivity indicates active Hepatitis B infection.
  • Anti-HBc IgM positivity confirms acute Hepatitis B infection.
  • Anti-HBc IgG indicates past exposure or chronic infection.
  • Negative Anti-HCV rules out Hepatitis C.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy came to emergency department with c/o fever for a week, tender, hepatomegaly, jaundice, calf pain, mild sore throat and conjunctival suffusion. No c/o vomiting, cough and haemorrhage. Urine output normal. No travel history. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical features disease looks like  leptospirosis.

Leptospira are actively motile spirochetes with characteristic hooked ends.

Most important pathogen is L interrogans which cause weil’s disease. L biflexo in non pathogenic saprophyte and leptospira canicola cause canicala fever which present as influenza like illness or aseptic meningitis. 

Transmission occurs by 3 R

Rat

Rice flield

Rain

It is zoonotic disease

Growth can be done on EMJH medium.

These organisms can not be seen under light microscopy, we have to use dark field microscopes.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Chikungunya - Typically presents with high fever, severe polyarthritis, rash, and no jaundice. Conjunctival suffusion and calf pain are not typical.
  • Choice C: Hepatitis A - Can cause fever, jaundice, and hepatomegaly, but does not typically present with calf pain or conjunctival suffusion. It is also associated with nausea, vomiting, and anorexia, which are absent in this case.
  • Choice D: Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever - This would present with high fever, hemorrhagic manifestations (petechiae, gum bleeding, etc.), and plasma leakage (pleural effusion, ascites). The absence of hemorrhage and shock symptoms makes dengue unlikely.

Key Takeaways:

  • Leptospirosis should be suspected in patients with fever, jaundice, calf pain, and conjunctival suffusion.
  • The “3 R’s” (Rat, Rice field, Rain) highlight common sources of infection.
  • Dengue hemorrhagic fever is associated with bleeding signs, which are absent here.
  • Diagnosis of leptospirosis is confirmed via serology or culture on EMJH medium.

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
Pseudo membrane contains leukocytes, fibrin and cellular debris

questions.text: What is false about pseudomembranous colitis/C. difficile?
questions.solution:
Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by Cl difficile.

Name Cl difficile is given because it is difficult to grow.

It occurs 2-3 days after taking some antibiotics. Like ampicillin, clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins.

This condition is uncommon in children and rare in infants.

Pseudomembran is formed in the intestine. It is made up of leukocyte, fibrin and cellular debris.

This condition occurs because of toxin production.

IgM has no diagnostic role.

Oral fidaxomicin is used as treatment.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment (True Statement)
    • Fidaxomicin is a macrolide-like antibiotic specifically used to treat difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD).
    • Vancomycin (oral) and metronidazole are also used, but fidaxomicin has a lower recurrence rate.
  • Choice C: It is toxin-mediated (True Statement)
    • difficile produces two main toxins:
      • Toxin A (Enterotoxin) → Causes diarrhea by damaging intestinal mucosa.
      • Toxin B (Cytotoxin) → More potent; disrupts cytoskeleton, leading to cell death.
    • These toxins cause inflammation and pseudomembrane formation.
  • Choice D: Pseudomembrane contains leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris (True Statement)
    • The pseudomembrane is composed of necrotic epithelial cells, inflammatory cells (leukocytes), fibrin, and cellular debris.
    • It forms in the colon, leading to pseudomembranous colitis, which appears as yellowish-white plaques on endoscopy.

Key Takeaways:

  • C.difficile infection is caused by toxin-producing strains, leading to pseudomembranous colitis.
  • IgM has NO role in diagnosis. Diagnosis is based on stool toxin tests and PCR.
  • Oral fidaxomicin is a treatment option along with vancomycin and metronidazole.
  • Pseudomembranes contain leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris.

questions.text: A patient was admitted due to sepsis and broad spectrum antibiotic started. She developed diarrhea. What is used to identify the etiology of diarrhea?
questions.solution:
This case looks like antibiotic associated diarrhea.

Most common organism which causes this is Cl difficile.

It is acquired from the hospital most of the time.

Risk factors:

Clindamycin

Ampicillin

Cephalosporin

Piperacillintazobactum

Other risk factors are:

Old age, greater severity of underlying illness

Gastrointestinal surgery

Used electric thermometer

Central tube feeding

Antacid use

Proton pump inhibitor

To diagnose this condition GDH antigen and toxin assay are done.

Stool microscopy has no role

Aerobic culture has no role as Cl difficile are difficult to grown and they are anaerobic

GDH assay has less sensitivity.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Correct A: GDH Ag only (Incorrect)
    • GDH antigen only detects the presence of C. difficile but does not confirm whether the strain is toxin-producing.
    • A positive GDH test must be followed by a toxin assay to confirm CDAD.
  • Correct C: Stool microscopy (Incorrect)
    • Microscopy is NOT useful because:
      • It does not detect C. difficile (which requires anaerobic culture).
      • White blood cells (WBCs) or fecal leukocytes may be present but are nonspecific for CDAD.
  • Correct D: Aerobic culture (Incorrect)
    • c. difficile is an obligate anaerobe, meaning it will NOT grow in aerobic culture.
    • Even in anaerobic culture, it takes too long (48-72 hours) and is not routinely done.

Key Takeaways:

  • difficile is the most common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea.
  • Risk factors include broad-spectrum antibiotic use (clindamycin, cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones), old age, and hospitalization.
  • Diagnosis requires GDH antigen + Toxin Assay (ELISA/PCR).
  • Stool microscopy and aerobic culture are NOT useful in diagnosing C. difficile infection.

questions.text: A soldier presented with fever, myalgia, rash in body sparing palm and sole. Five other soldiers in the troop were also affected with similar illness. H/o exposure to body lice present. Choose the correct causative organism?
questions.solution:
R prowazekii is a species of gram negative alphaproteobacteria, obligate intracellular parasite, aerobic bacillus species that is the etiological agent of epidemic typhus transmitted by feces of lice.

Clinical features of epidemic typhus are fever chills, headache, rapid breathing, body and muscle ache, rash, cough, nausea, vomiting.

Rash generally spares the palm and sole.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice B: R. typhi (Incorrect)
    • Causes Endemic (Murine) Typhus, which is spread by fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis), not body lice.
    • Rash does not typically spare the palms and soles.
  • Choice C: R. akari (Incorrect)
    • Causes Rickettsialpox, which is transmitted by mites (rodent-associated), not lice.
    • Presents with an eschar at the bite site, fever, and a generalized vesicular rash.
  • Choice D: R. conorii (Incorrect)
    • Causes Mediterranean Spotted Fever (Boutonneuse fever), transmitted by ticks.
    • Rash does NOT spare the palms and soles.
    • Often presents with a black eschar (tâche noire) at the bite site.

Key Takeaways:

  • Epidemic typhus (R. prowazekii) is transmitted by body lice feces and occurs in crowded conditions (e.g., military camps, prisons).
  • The rash of epidemic typhus spares the palms and soles.
  • Murine typhus (R. typhi) is flea-borne, while Mediterranean spotted fever (R. conorii) is tick-borne.
  • R.akari causes rickettsialpox, with a vesicular rash and an eschar.

questions.text: A diabetic patient had rhinitis, facial swelling. Biopsy showed aseptate hyphae with irregular obtuse branching. Drug of choice for this?
questions.solution:
Diabetic patients are prone to many opportunistic infections. Aspergillus is one of the common opportunistic infections in Diabetic patients. Mucormycosis is also another fungus which is prone in diabetic patients.

It causes rhinitis and facial swelling can occur in both.

Drug of choice for invasive fungus infection are Amphotericin B

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice B: Fluconazole (Incorrect)
    • Not effective against Mucormycosis; mainly used for Candida infections.
  • Choice C: Voriconazole (Incorrect)
    • Effective against Aspergillus, but not Mucorales.
    • Mucormycosis requires Amphotericin B, not Voriconazole.
  • Choice D: Caspofungin (Incorrect)
    • Echinocandins (e.g., Caspofungin) are ineffective against Mucormycosis.
    • Used primarily for Candida and Aspergillus infections.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mucormycosis is common in uncontrolled diabetics, especially those with DKA.
  • Presents with rhino-orbital-cerebral involvement (sinusitis, facial swelling, black eschar).
  • Histology shows broad, aseptate hyphae with irregular, obtuse-angle branching.
  • Drug of choice: Liposomal Amphotericin B.

choices.text: Stop breast feeding and start ART
Test for IgM antibodies of giardia and start antibiotics.

questions.text: A 4 month old child born to HIV positive mother developed recurrent diarrhea. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
A 4 month old child born to an HIV positive mother develops recurrent diarrhea.

Now there are chances the child may have got HIV infection from mother. Now in pediatric patients we can not detect antibodies to diagnose HIV.

Because antibodies can come from the mother also.

So PCR is to be done or antigen detection should be done.

Among given options, Dried blood for PCR is the best option available that is the answer.

Incorrect options explanation :

Choice A for Hiv positive mothers , she should continue breast feeding there is no need to stop breastfeeding. So this is the wrong option.

Choice C is wrong because Antibody based test have no role.

Choice D is also not true because antibody to giardia has no role. And giving antibiotics has less role.

Key Takeaways:

  • HIV DNA PCR is the best diagnostic test for infants <18 months.
  • Maternal HIV antibodies persist in infants, making antibody-based tests unreliable.
  • Breastfeeding should be continued if the mother is on ART.
  • Recurrent diarrhea in an HIV-exposed infant raises concern for perinatal HIV infection.

choices.text: Caused by both bacteria and fungi

questions.text: A 45 old farmer was admitted with sinuses with discharging granules in the foot. Microscopy of the granule shown in the image. Choose the true statement.
questions.solution:
This is a case of mycetoma.

Mycetoma is a disease caused by certain type of bacteria and fungi found in soil and water.

These bacteria and fungi enter the body through a break in skin, often on a person’s foot.

Clinical feature

Starts with a painless lump under the skin.

Progresses to open infection discharging small Grains containing fungal spores

Causes swollen, disfigured body parts most commonly hand , feet , back and buttocks.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: It causes only superficial disease (Incorrect)
    • Mycetoma starts as a subcutaneous infection but can invade deeper tissues, bones, and even spread hematogenously.
    • It does not remain superficial.
  • Choice C: Caused by both bacteria and fungi (Incorrect)
    • Mycetoma is caused by either bacteria (actinomycetoma) or fungi (eumycetoma), but not both at the same time.
    • Bacterial mycetoma → Nocardia, Actinomadura, Streptomyces species.
    • Fungal mycetoma → Madurella, Pseudallescheria, Acremonium species.
  • Choice D: Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon (Incorrect)
    • The Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon refers to eosinophilic material deposition around pathogens, seen in parasitic, fungal, and bacterial infections.
    • It is observed in sporotrichosis, actinomycosis, schistosomiasis, and some mycetomas, but it is not a defining feature of mycetoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mycetoma spreads hematogenously, leading to bone involvement (osteomyelitis).
  • It is caused by either bacteria (actinomycetoma) or fungi (eumycetoma), but not both.
  • It is not just a superficial disease; it can be deeply invasive.
  • Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is not a defining characteristic of mycetoma.

questions.text: Microfilaria with sheathed tail and two nucleus in the tail tip suggestive of
questions.solution:
Microfilaria are different for different spp

Some are sheathed, some are non sheathed.
Some have nuclei up to tail,

Some have no nuclei in tail.

Sheathed microfilariae - w bancrofti, loa loa, B malayi

Non sheathed microfilariae - M perstans, M ozzardi, M streptocerca, O volvulus

Sheathed microfilariae with nuclei up ottail tip - B malayi, loa loa

Sheathed microfilariae with tail- tip free from nuclei - W bancrofti
Unsheathed microfilariae with nuclei upto tail tip – M perstans, M streptocerca

Unsheathed microfilariae with tail tip free from nuclei - M ozzardi, O volvulus

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Loa loa (Incorrect)
    • Loa loa is sheathed and has continuous nuclei up to the tail tip, not two discrete nuclei.
    • It causes Loiasis, transmitted by Chrysops (deer fly).
  • Choice C: Wuchereria bancrofti (Incorrect)
    • W. bancrofti is sheathed, but it has no nuclei in the tail tip.
    • It is responsible for 90% of lymphatic filariasis cases worldwide.
  • Choice D: Mansonella ozzardi (Incorrect)
    • M. ozzardi is unsheathed and has no nuclei in the tail tip.
    • It is transmitted by biting midges (Culicoides) and black flies (Simulium).

Key Takeaways:

  • Brugia malayi is sheathed and has two nuclei at the tail tip.
  • Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed but has no nuclei at the tail tip.
  • Loa loa is sheathed with continuous nuclei up to the tail tip.
  • Mansonella ozzardi is unsheathed and has no nuclei in the tail tip.

choices.text: Inhibits the release of Acetyl choline

questions.text: Choose the correct MoA of Botulinum toxin.
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin the most potent of neurotoxin, produce paralysis by blocking presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter ( Acetylcholine) at the neuromuscular junction, with reversible chemical denervation of the muscle fibre, thereby inducing partial paralysis and atrophy.

Botulinum toxin is used for treatment, botulinum toxin is injected, it blocks certain nerve signals that make muscle contrast. The muscle relaxes, reducing unwanted wrinkles. This effect lasts about 3-6 months.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Stimulate nicotinic receptors (Incorrect)
    • Botulinum toxin does not stimulate nicotinic receptors; instead, it prevents ACh release, thereby reducing their activation.
  • Choice C: Stimulate muscarinic receptors (Incorrect)
    • Muscarinic receptors are stimulated by acetylcholine, but botulinum toxin prevents ACh release, leading to muscle paralysis and autonomic dysfunction.
  • Choice D: Stimulate the release of norepinephrine (Incorrect)
    • Botulinum toxin does not affect norepinephrine release; it specifically targets ACh release at cholinergic synapses.

Key Takeaways:

  • Botulinum toxin inhibits ACh release, causing flaccid paralysis.
  • It works by cleaving SNARE proteins, preventing vesicle fusion at presynaptic terminals.
  • Used therapeutically for wrinkle reduction, muscle spasms, dystonia, and hyperhidrosis.

questions.text: Broken vaccine vial is discarded in?
questions.solution: Biomedical waste guides are revised with time to time, most recent guidelines are as below.

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever, headache, vomiting, altered sensorium with neck rigidity. CSF analysis shows slight decrease in glucose and increase in proteins. Microscopy - predominantly lymphocytes seen. A coagulum of CSF SEEN AS SHOWN IN THE IMAGE. Choose the correct diagnosis
questions.solution:
Given history suggests Tubercular meningitis. In Tb meningitis there is decrease in sugar and high protein and predominant cells are lymphocytes. Chest x ray also shows lung fibrosis and hilar lymphadenopathy.

In pyogenic meningitis predominant cells are neutrophils, and sugar decreases and protein increases.

In viral meningitis sugar and protein may remain normal.

Chemical meningitis is also excluded on the basis of normal sugar and protein.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Pyogenic meningitis (Incorrect)
    • CSF: ↓↓ Glucose, ↑↑ Protein, Predominantly neutrophils (not lymphocytes).
    • Caused by bacterial infections (e.g., S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae).
    • CSF coagulum is not seen in pyogenic meningitis.
  • Choice B: Viral meningitis (Incorrect)
    • CSF: Normal or mild ↓ Glucose, Mild ↑ Protein, Predominantly lymphocytes.
    • Caused by enteroviruses, HSV, mumps, etc.
    • No coagulum formation in CSF.
  • Choice D: Chemical meningitis (Incorrect)
    • Caused by intrathecal drugs or rupture of dermoid cysts, leading to aseptic inflammation.
    • CSF glucose & protein remain normal or mildly altered.
    • No coagulum formation in CSF.

Key Takeaways:

  • TB meningitis presents with lymphocytic pleocytosis, ↓ glucose, ↑ proteins, and CSF coagulum.
  • Pyogenic meningitis shows neutrophilic predominance, very low glucose, and high protein.
  • Viral meningitis usually has normal glucose and proteins with lymphocytic predominance.
  • CSF coagulum ("spider web clot") is a hallmark of TB meningitis.

questions.text: MDR TB refers to resistant to
questions.solution:
Multi drug resistant TB is caused by TB bacteria that are resistant to at least isoniazid and rifampicin.

Two most potent TB drugs. These drugs are used to treat all persons with TB disease.

Sign and symptom of Multidrug resistant TB

Bad cough for longer than 3 weeks either dry, yellow or green mucus and in some cases bloody mucus.

Wt loss

Fatigue

Shortness of breath

Fever

Night sweat

Lack of appetite

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: Rifampicin + Kanamycin (Incorrect)
    • Kanamycin is a second-line injectable drug, and its resistance is not required for MDR-TB classification.
  • Choice B: Isoniazid + Rifampicin + Kanamycin (Incorrect)
    • Resistance to kanamycin along with MDR-TB would indicate pre-XDR TB (Pre-Extensively Drug-Resistant TB), not MDR-TB.
  • Choice D: Isoniazid + Fluoroquinolones (Incorrect)
    • Fluoroquinolone resistance suggests XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant TB), not MDR-TB.

Key Takeaways:

  • MDR-TB = Resistance to Isoniazid + Rifampicin.
  • Pre-XDR-TB = MDR-TB + Resistance to either a fluoroquinolone or a second-line injectable drug (kanamycin, amikacin, capreomycin).
  • XDR-TB = MDR-TB + Resistance to both fluoroquinolones and a second-line injectable drug.

questions.text: A 20-year female working in a village school developed watery diarrhea with rice water stool. The pathogen responsible for this condition acts on
questions.solution:
The given case is of Cholera. Which is caused by V cholera. It is gram negative bacilli. It is comma shaped .

This bacteria produces a toxin which works on GM 1 Ganglioside receptor

Clinical feature is that it causes severe diarrhea. Stool is like a rice watery stool.

Patients may have low blood pressure.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice B: GM2 Ganglioside Receptor (Incorrect)
    • GM2 is associated with Tay-Sachs disease and has no role in cholera pathogenesis.
  • Choice C: Cerebro Ganglioside Receptor (Incorrect)
    • No known bacterial toxin acts specifically on cerebro gangliosides.
  • Choice D: Sphingomyelin Receptor (Incorrect)
    • Some toxins (e.g., sphingomyelinase C from Staphylococcus aureus or Listeria monocytogenes) act on sphingomyelin, but not cholera toxin.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells.
  • It activates adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP, leading to massive Cl- and water loss.
  • Characteristic "rice water" stools are seen, leading to severe dehydration and hypotension.

questions.text: A female came with a clinical condition as shown in the image. HPE shows she's having high risk for squamous cell atypia. Which is responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Warts are caused by Human papillomavirus ( HPV)

HPV DNA of oncogenic types ( High risk) in HPV 16,18,31,33, and 45 – associated with cervical cancer

HPV 6 and 11 ( Low risk HPV) associated with precursor lesions of cervical cancer  ( CIN) and condyloma acuminatum.

In patients with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, squamous cell cancer develop frequently at sites infected with HPV types including 5 and 8.

E6 and E 7 genes of HPV are responsible for carcinogenicity'

Common warts ( Verruca vulgaris) are found in as many as 25 % of some group and are most prevalent among children.

Condyloma acuminatum ( Anogenital warts) ais one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • Choice A: HPV 5 (Incorrect)
    • HPV 5 and 8 are linked to epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare genetic disorder leading to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, not anogenital warts.
  • Choice C: HPV 18 (Incorrect)
    • HPV 16 and 18 are high-risk oncogenic HPV types linked to cervical cancer and high-grade CIN, not common anogenital warts.
  • Choice D: HPV 7 (Incorrect)
    • HPV 7 is associated with butcher’s warts, seen in people who handle raw meat, not genital warts.

Key Takeaways:

  • HPV 6 & 11 → Low-risk HPV, responsible for condyloma acuminatum (anogenital warts).
  • HPV 16 & 18 → High-risk HPV, associated with cervical cancer & CIN.
  • HPV 5 & 8 → Linked to epidermodysplasia verruciformis.
  • E6 & E7 oncogenes of HPV interfere with p53 & Rb, contributing to carcinogenesis.
